div.p:
XXVI 238
Sedg My men having never had
firearms in their hands before
found it so difficult to
hold the muskets steady on
the flash of fire in the pan
that they naturally expected me
4 to furnish ourthem with "gun
medicine" - without which
theit is almost universally
believed no one can shoot
straight - Great expectations
had been formed ^ when I perceived by the
on my arrival among ^ the Makololo on the subject but
having invariably declined
to decievedeceive them as some
do for their own profit - my
72 men now concievedconceived that
I would ^ at last consent and thereby relieve myself from
the hard work of hunting
by employing them after due
medication This
I was most willing to do if I could have
done it honestly
for having but little of the
hunting furore in my
composition, I always preferred
eating the game to killing
it - Sulphur is the remedy
most admired - And I
remember Sechele giving
a large price for a very
small bit - He also gave
some elephantselephants' tusks worth
£30 for another medicine
which a was to make him
invulnerable to musket balls
239
As I invariably recommended
trial that these experiments
things ˄ should be tested by experiments
a calf was anointed with
a charm and tied to a
tree - It proved decisive,
and Sechele remarked it was
"pleasanter to be decieveddeceived than
undecievedundeceived" - I offered sulphur
for the same purpose - but
that was declined even when
a person came afterwards
and rubbed his hands with
a little before a trial of shooting

I explained to my man
the nature of the gun and
tried to teach them but they
would soon have expended
73 all the ammunition in our
possession and I was thus
obliged to do all the shooting
myself ever afterwards - Their inability was
rather a misfortune for
in consequence of working
too soon after having been
bitten by the lion the bone
of the arm had not united
well - Continual hard
manual labour and some
falls from oxback lengthened
the ligament by which a
false the ends of the bones
were united and a false
joint was the consequence
240
The limb has never been painful
like those of my companions
on the day of the rencontre
with the lion but there
being a joint too many
I could not steady the rifle
and I was always obliged
to shoot with the piece
resting on the left shoulder
I wanted steadiness of aim
aim and it always happened
Sedgwick that the more hungry the
party became the more
frequent were my misses
I missed the animals

179
74 We spent a Sunday in
our way up to the confluence
of the Leeba and Leeambye
Rains haved fallen here
before we came and the
woods had put on their
gayest hue - Flowers of
great beauty and curious
forms grow everywhere
They are unlike those in
the South and so are the
trees - Many of the forest
tree ˄ leaves are palmated and
largely developed - Many
The trunks of the trees
are covered with f Lichens
241
and the abundance of ferns
which appear in the forest
shewsshows we are now in a
more humid climate than
any to the South of the
Barotse valley - The
ground begins to swarm
with insect youth and
in the cool pleasant morning
the welkin rings with the
singing of birds which areis
not so delightful as, the
notes of birds at home
because I have not been
familiar with them from
infancy - They do however
strike the mind as the
by their loudness and variety
as the very an wellings forth
75 from joysome hearts of
praise to Him who fills them
with overflowing gladness
All ˄ of us rise early to enjoy
the luscious balmy air
of the morning - We have
their worship, and amidst
all the beauty and lovelinessloveliness
with which we are surrounded
there is still a feeling of want
in the soul in viewing one's
poor companions and hearing
bitter words impure words
jarring to the ear in the perfection
by of whi the scenes of nature
242
and a longing that both their
hearts and ours should be
brought into harmony with the
Great Father of Spirits - I pointed
out the remedy which God
has presented to us all in the
unexpressibly precious gift
of His own Son on whom
the Lord "laid the iniquity of
of us all" in as usual the
simplest words I could muster
The great difficulty in dealing
with these people is to
make the subject plain
enough - The minds of the
auditors cannot be understood
by one who has not mingled
much with them - They readily
pray for the forgiveness of sins
and then sin again - confess
76 the evil of it and there the
matter ends -

Mead I shall not often advert
to their depravity - My practice
has always been to apply
the remedy ˄ for this with all the ˄ possible vigour
but never allow my own
mind to dwell on the dark side
shades ^ of men's characters - Those who
I have never been able to
draw pictures of guilt in order
as if that could to awaken Christian sympathy
The evil is there - But all
around in this fair creation
243
are scenes of beauty - and to
turn from there to ponder
on scenes of sin cannot
promote a healthy state of
the faculties - I attribute
much of the health I haenjoy
to following the plan
adopted by most physicians
of active laborious efforts
to assist the needy - while
and at the same time
following the delightful studies
of some department of
natural history - The mass
of human misery and sin
we endeavour to alleviate
and cure may be likened
to the impure sickness orand
impurity of some of the back
slums of great cities - One
contents himself by ministering
77 to the sick and trying to
remove its causes without
remaining longer in the
filth than ˄ is necessary for his
work - Another equally
anxious for the public good
stir up every cesspool
that he may describe its
reeking vapours and by
long contact with impurities
becomes himself infected
sickens and dies

244
The men went about during
the day and brought back
wild fruits of several varieties
I had not hitherto seen - One
called Mogametla-etsa Mogametsa
is a bean with a q little pulp
round it which looks like
tastes like sponge biscuit
Another ˄ named Mawa grows abundantly on
a low bush - There are many
berries and edible bulbs
almost everywhere - The
Mamosho or Moshomosho
and Milo a medlar was
to be found near our
encampment - The latter
two are good if indeed one
can be a good judge who
felt quite disposed to
78 pass a favourable verdict
on every fruit which
had the good character
of being eatable at all
Many however are better
than our crab apple and
or slowesloe & had they half the care
and culture these have
enjoyed might take high
rank among the fruits of
of the world - All that the
Africans have thought
of has been present
gratification and now
as I sometimes deposit
245
date seeds in the soil and tell
them I have no hope whatever
of seeing the fruit it seems
to them like what the deed
of the South Sea Islanders
appears to us when they
planted iron nails in their
gardens

There are many fruits
and berries in the forests
the uses of which are
unknown to my companions
Great numbers of a kind
of palm I have never met
before arewere seen growing
at and below the confluence
Loeti of the Loeti & Leeambye - the
seed probably came down
that river - It is nearly
as tall as the Palmyra
The fruit is larger than of
79 that of species - It is about
4 inches in its long diameter
and has a soft yellow
pulp round the kernel
or seed - When ripe this
is fluid and stringy like
the mango and not very
pleasant to eat -

Before we came to
the confluence of the Leeba
and Leeambye we find
the banks twenty feet high
and composed of marly
sandstone - They are covered
246
with the trees and the left bank
has the TsétseTsetse and elephants
I suspect it has some
connection with this animal
for the Portuguese in the
district of Tete call it the
(Musca da Elephant) Musc the Elephant fly

The water of inundation
covers even these lofty
banks but does not stand
long upon them hence
theis crop of trees - Where
it stands for any length
of time trees cannot live
On the right bank or
that in which the Loeti
a river 80 or 100 feet br flows
there is an extensive country
flat elevated country called
Mango Mango which though
covered with grass is
destitute in a great
80 measure of trees

Powell Flocks of green pigeons
rose from the trees as
we passed along the banks
and the notes of many
birds told that we were
now among strangers
but I could make no
collection as I was pro-
ceeding on the plan of having
as much little luggage as
possible so as not to
excite the cupidity of those
247
through whose country we
intended to pass - River birds
as the Ibis religiosa - small
snipes - ducks (- anas histrionica
geese and others come down
in great numbers with
the rising waters
One goose cannot rise
from the wing and we
say how men with
light canoes could spear
catch them in a race -

B Vast shoals of fish
come down the Leeambye
as we observed they
do in the Zouga with
the rising waters - They
are probably induced to this
migration by the increased
rapidity of the current dis-
-lodging them from their
81 old pasture grounds - Insects
constitute but a small
portion of the food of many
fish - Fine vegetable
matter like slender mosses
is devoured greedily and
as they are dislodged from
the main stream by the
force of the current and
find abundant pasture
on the flooded plains the
whole community becomes
disturbed and wanders

248
the Mosala - (Clarias Capensis
(the Glanis siluris) - mullet - (Mugil
Africanus) and other fishes
spread over the Barotse valley
in such numbers that when
the waters retire all the people
are employed in cutting them
up and drying them in
the sun - The supply exceeds
the demand and the land
and in numerous places
is said to emit a most
offensive smell - WheverWherever
you see the ZambesiZambezi
in the centre of the country
it is remarkable for the
abundance of animal life
in anand ˄ on its waters and upon
the ajacentadjacent banks

We passed great numbers
of hipp hippopotami - They
are very numerous in
the parts of he river where
they are never hunted
The males appear of a dark
82 colour - The females of
yellowish brown - There
is not such a complete
separation of the sexes among
them as among elephants,
They spend most of their
time on the water lolling about
in a listless dreamy manner
When they come out of
water by night they crop off
249
the soft succulent grasses
very neatly, when they blow
they puff up the water about
three feet high

On the 27th December we were
at the confluence of the Leeba
Masiko and Leeambye - Masiko the
Barotse chief for whom
we had some captives lived
nearly due East of this
point - They were two little
boys, a little girl & a young
man and two middle aged
women one of these was
a member of
the Babimpe tribe
who knock
out both upper
& lower front
teeth as a distinction - As we had been
informed by the captives
on the previous Sunday that Masiko
was in the habit of seizing
all orphans and those who
have no powerful friend
in the tribe whose protection
they can claim, and selling
Mambari them for clothing to the Mambari
we thought the objection
of the women to go first to
his town before seeing their
83 friends quite reasonable,
and resolved to send a party
of our own people to see
them safely among their
relatives - I told the ˄ captive young
man to tell Masiko that he
was very unlike his father
Santuru who had refused
to sell his people to Mambari
250
He will probably be afraid to
deliver such a message
himself but it is meant
for his people and they will
circulate it pretty widely untilluntil
and Masiko may yet feel
a little pressure from without
We sent a Batoka man Mosantu the Batoka of
our party and
his companions ^ with the captives
The Barotse whom we had
being unable ˄ were unwilling to go
to Masiko as they owe him
allegiance and while they
continue with the Makololo
our considered rebels - The
message by the Ba Mosantu
was that "I was sorry to
find that Santuru had not
borne a wiser son - Santuru
loved to govern ˄ men children but
Masiko wanted to govern
wild beasts only as he sold
84 his people to the Mambari"
adding an explanation of the
return of the captives - and
an injunction to him to live
in peace & prevent his people kidnapping
the children and canoes
of the Makololo - as a continuance
in these deeds would lead to the
war which I wished to prevent
He was also instructed to say
if we Masiko wanted fuller
explanation of my views
he must send a sensible man
251
to talk with me at the first town
of the Balonda to which I was
about to proceed

Mosantu We ferried Mosantu over
to the left bank of the Leeba
The journey required five days
but it cannot have been
at a quicker rate more than ten or twelve miles
per day for the children were
not more than between
seven and eight years of
age and unable to walk
fast in a hot sun -

Leaving Mosantu to
pursue his course we
shall take but one glance
down the river - which we
are now about to leave
for it comes nowat this point from
the Eastward and our
course is to be directed
to the N -North N - W - North West if we mean
85 to go to LoandoLuanda in Angola
- From the confluence where
we now are down
to Mosioatunya there are
many long reaches where
a considerable vessel equal
to the Thame'sThames Steamers
plying between the bridges
could sail as freely as
they do on the Thames
It is often as broad as that
river at London bridge
252
There are however many
and serious obstacles to
a continued navigation
for hundreds of miles at
a stretch - About ten miles
below the confluence of
the Loeti for instance there are many
large sandbanks in the
stream - but then you have
a hundred miles to the R -River
Simah where a Thames
Steamer could ply at all
times of the year, and again the
space between Simah &
Katima-moleloKatima Mulilo Katimal MoleloKatima Mulilo has five
or six rapids with reaches
cataracts one of which
Gonye could not be
passed at any time of
the year without portage -
Between these rapids
86 there are reaches of still
deep water of several
miles in length - Beyond
Katima moleloKatima Mulilo to the confluence
of the Chobe you have nearly
a hundred miles ˄ again of a river capable of being
navigated in the same
way as in the Barotse valley -

Berry Now I do not say that
this part of the river presents
a very inviting prospect
for European enterprise
but where we have a pathway
which but requires the
253
formation of locks portages
to make it equal to our canals for
hundreds of miles, where
the philosophers supposed
there was nought but
an extreme sandy desert
we must confess that
the future partakesadverts at least
of the elements of hope -
My deliberate conviction
was that thise part of the country
indicated is as capable of
supporting millions of
inhabitants as it is of
its thousands - The grass
of the Barotse valley for
instance in such a densely
matted mass that when
fallen down the stalks
bear each other up so
that one feels as if
walking on the sheaves
87 of a hay stack - and the
Leche's nestle under it
to bring forth their young
This, if placed under the plough ^ instead of being
mere pasturage
would fill
millions of
mouths

We now began to
ascend the Leeba - The ˄ water is black
in colour as compared
with the main stream which
here assumes the name
Kabompo - The Leeba
flows placidly and unlike
the parent streamriver recievesreceives
numbers of little rivulets
from both l sides
254
It winds slowly through the
most lovely meadows each
of which has either a soft
sedgy centre, large pond or
trickling rill down the middle,
The trees are now covered
with a profusion of the
freshest foliage and seen
planted in groups of such
pleasant graceful outline
that art could add no
additional charm - The
grass which had been
burned off and was
growing again after the
rains was short and
green and all the scenery
is so like that of a
carefully tended gentleman's
park that one is scarcely
reminded to that he is in
88 uncultivated regions - I suspect
that the level meadows
are inundated annually
for the spots on which
the trees stand are elevated
a li three three or four feet above
them and these elevations
being of different shapes
give the strange variety
of outline of the park
like woods - Numbers of
a fresh water shell are
scattered all over these
valliesvalleys too - The elevations
255
too as I have observed elsewhere
are of soft sandy soil and
the meadows of black
rich alluvial soil loam
There are many beautiful
flowers and many bees
to sip their nectar - We found
plenty of honey in the woods
and saw the stages on
which the Balonda dry
their meat when they come
down to hunt and gather
the produce of the bees
wild hives - In some
one part we came upon
groups of lofty trees as
as straight as with festoons
of orchilla weed hanging from
the branches - This which is
used as a dye stuff is found
nowhere in the South dry
country in the South - It
89 prefers the humid climates
near the West Coast

One of our people was
bitten by a serpent which
must have been harmless
for he felt no harm - his
companions ascribed his
escape from danger to
many of them being present
and seeing the serpent -
A large buffalo was shot
and ran into the thickest
256
part of the forest bleeding profusely
The young men went on his
trail and though the vegetation
was so dense no one could
have run more than a few
yards most of them went
along quite carelessly picking
and eating up a fruit of the melon
Mponko family called Mponko
When he heard them approach
he always fled shifting his
stand and doubling on his
course in the most
remarkable manner - In
other cases I have known
them turn back to a point
a few yards from their
own trail and then lie
down in a hollow waiting
for the hunter to come up
Though a heavy lumbering
looking animal his charge
is then terrific and rapid
90 More accidents happen
with the buffaloes and the black
Rhinoceros than with the
lion - Though all are aware
of the cunning of the buffalo
when wounded - our young
men went on to him
quite carelessly - They never
lose their presence of mind
but as he charges back
in a forest dart dexterously
257
out of his way behind a tree
and wheeling round it stab
him as he passes

Mead A tree in flower brought
the pleasant scent of hawthorn hedges
back to memory for its
leaves flowers ˄ scent and fruit resembled
those of the hawthorn - only
the flowers here were as large
aas a h dog roses and the "haws"
were like ˄ boysboys' marbles - The
flowers smell sweetly while few in
the South emit
aught but
a sentscent at all
or only a
nauseous
odour and
aA botanist would find a
rich harvest of them on
the banks of the Leeba - This
would be his best season
for the flowers all run
so rapidly to seed - and
then insects of every shape
spring into existence to
devour them - The climbing
plants display great vigour
91 of growth growth being not
only thick in the trunk but
thick at the very point in
the manner of quickly
growing asparagus - The
Maroro Maroro or Malolo now
appears and is abundant
all in many parts between
this and Angola - It is a
small bush with a yellow
258
fruit and in its appearance
a dwarf Anona - The taste
is sweet and itsthe fruit is
wholesomwholesome though & It f is
full of seeds in the manner
of the sweet sop

On the 28th we slept on
a spot on the right back
from which had just
emerged two broods of alligators
We had seen many young
ones as we came up - so ^ this seems to
be their time
of coming
forth
the river sunning themselves
in company with the old
on sand banks - We made
our fire in ˄ one of the deserted nests
Sedg [which wasere strewed all over
with the broken shells - - When
atAt the Zouga we ob saw
sixty eggs taken out of one
such nest - They are
92 about the size of those
of al goose only the eggs
of the alligator are of
the same diameter at
both l ends and the ˄ white shell is
partially elastic from having
a strong internal membrane
and but little lime in its
composition - The distance
from the water was about
one ten feet and there was
evidence of the same place
259
having been used for the same
purpose in former years
- A broad path led up from
the water to the nest and the
dam it was said by my
companions after depositing
the eggs covers them up
and returns to assist
93 the young out of the egg
place of confinement
and out of the egg - She leads
them to the edge of the water
and then leaves them to catch
small fish for themselves - Such assistance
seems necessary
for here they
had besides
the tough
membrane
of the shell
four inches
of earth upon
them, but
they do not
require immediate
aid for food
because they
all retain a
portion of yolk
equal to that
of a henshen's egg
in a membrane
in the abdomen
as a stock of
nutriment in
beginning independantindependent
existence by catching fish
Fish is the principal food
of both small and large
and they are much assisted
in catching them by their
broad scaly tails - Sometimes
an alligator viewing a
man in the water from
the opposite bank rushes
accros across the stream
with wonderful agility
as is seen by the high
ripple he makes on
the surface - but in general
they act by stealth - sinking
beneath the surface
as soon as they see
man - - They seldom
leave the water
to catch prey
but enjoy
260
the sun basking in the sun In walking
along the bank
of the Zouga
once a
small one
about three feet long
made a rush
at my feet
and made
me rush
quickly in
another
direction but
this is unusual
for I never
heard of
another case
like it -
A ˄ wounded leché chased
into any of
the lagoons
in the Barotse
valley wound
or a man or dog
going in for
the purpose
of bringing
out a dead
one is almost
sure to be seized
though the alligators seldom
appear on
the surface
and whenWhen employed in looking
out for food ˄ they keep out
of sight - TheThey fish chiefly
by night - When eating
they make a loud champing
noise which when once
heard is never forgotten -

Sedg
The young in this instance
do not appear wary
They were about sixten inches
long - with yellow eyes and
pupil a perpendicular slit
They were all marked with
transverse stripes of pale
green and brown half
an inch broad - When
speared they bit the spear
savagely though their
teeth were but partially
developed - uttering at the
same time a sharp bark
like that of a whelp
when it first begins to
use its voice - I could not
ascertain whether the dam
devours them as reported
or whether the IchneumenIchneumon
has the same reputation
her as in Egypt - Probably
the Barotse and Bayeiye
would not look upon
it as a benefactor - they
94
261
prefer to eat the eggs themselves
and be their own IchneumensIchneumons
The white of the egg does not
coagulate but the yolk
does and this is the only
part eaten

As population increases
they will decrease for their
nests will be oftener found
Their principal check on
their inordinate increase
seems to be man - They
are more savage
and commit more mischief
in the Zambesi ^ Leeambye than in
any other river - After
dancing young men run
down to the water to wash
ofoff the dust & perspiration
and cool themselves before
going to bed - and are thus
95 often swept away - One
wonders they are not afraid
but the fact is they have
as little sense of danger
impending over them as
the hare had of the hound
and in many rencontres
in which they escape
they had not time to be
afraid and laugh at the
circumstance afterwards
There is a want of calm
reflection - In many cases
